skill.name: ghe-report
skill.description:
Generate detailed reports with metrics, health checks, or epic-specific analysis. More comprehensive than quick status overview.

USE THIS SKILL WHEN:
- User asks for metrics, statistics, or performance report
- User asks for health check or compliance check
- User asks for epic report or epic status
- User wants detailed analysis, not just current state

REPORT TYPES:
- metrics: Throughput, cycle times, first-pass rates, demotion rates
- health: Compliance status, stale threads, violation history, memory bank status
- epic: Single epic details with thread history, progress, decisions

DO NOT USE THIS SKILL WHEN:
- User just wants quick status overview (use ghe-status)
- User wants to claim an issue (use ghe-claim)
- User wants to post a checkpoint (use ghe-checkpoint)
- User wants to transition phases (use ghe-transition)
skill.summary: Generate detailed workflow metrics, health assessments, and epic-specific analysis reports
skill.author: Emasoft

security_audit.summary: Static analysis detected 22 patterns flagged as potential security issues. Manual review confirms all findings are false positives caused by markdown syntax misinterpreted as code patterns. The backticks detected are markdown code formatting delimiters, not shell command execution. YAML frontmatter and heading markers were misidentified as cryptographic patterns. No actual security risks present. This is documentation-only content for generating workflow reports.

high_findings.title: Markdown Backticks Misidentified as Shell Command Execution
high_findings.description: Static scanner flagged 15 instances of backtick patterns as 'Ruby/shell backtick execution'. These are markdown code formatting delimiters (for file names, command examples, code blocks), not shell command execution syntax like `$(command)` or backticks in bash scripts. The skill is documentation-only and contains no executable code.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Clear evidence of markdown documentation patterns. Backticks are used exclusively for code formatting in documentation, with no actual shell command execution code present.

high_findings.title: Markdown Syntax Misidentified as Weak Cryptographic Algorithm
high_findings.description: Static scanner flagged YAML frontmatter and heading markers as 'weak cryptographic algorithm'. Line 3 contains YAML frontmatter delimiter `---`. Lines 87, 94, and 222 contain `#` symbols used for markdown headings and backticks for file naming examples. These are documentation syntax, not cryptographic code.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Standard markdown formatting syntax in documentation file. No cryptographic algorithms or implementations present.

high_findings.title: Documentation Path Reference Misidentified as Hidden File Access
high_findings.description: Static scanner flagged `~/.claude` as 'hidden file in home directory' access. This is a documentation reference explaining where plugin settings may be stored. The skill is documentation-only and contains no file system access code.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Documentation text describing valid path locations. No file access operations present in this documentation-only skill file.

high_findings.title: Workflow Documentation Misidentified as Network Reconnaissance
high_findings.description: Static scanner flagged text describing 'thread history (all DEV/TEST/REVIEW cycles)' as 'network reconnaissance'. This is legitimate project management documentation describing workflow tracking, not network activity scanning.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Documentation of project workflow phases. No network operations or reconnaissance code present.

content.value_statement: Users need detailed analysis of their GitHub Elements workflow performance. This skill generates comprehensive reports including metrics, health assessments, and epic-specific analysis to help teams understand their development velocity and identify areas for improvement.
actual_capabilities: Generate performance metrics reports showing throughput, cycle times, and quality indicators
Create workflow health assessments including compliance status and stale thread detection
Produce detailed epic-specific reports with thread history and progress tracking
Format reports with tables and structured data for easy analysis
Spawn the Hermes reporter agent to execute detailed report generation
limitations: Does not modify GitHub issues or workflow state - read-only analysis
Cannot access external systems beyond the connected GitHub repository
Report depth depends on available GitHub Elements data and thread history
Does not provide real-time notifications - reports are generated on demand

use_cases.title: Sprint Retrospective Analysis
use_cases.description: Generate a metrics report to review team performance during a sprint. Analyze throughput, cycle times, and first-pass review rates to identify bottlenecks and celebrate improvements.
use_cases.target_user: Scrum masters and team leads conducting sprint retrospectives

use_cases.title: Workflow Compliance Audit
use_cases.description: Run a health check report before a major release to ensure all workflow rules are being followed. Identify stale threads, review violation history, and verify memory bank synchronization.
use_cases.target_user: Release managers and quality assurance leads

use_cases.title: Epic Progress Review
use_cases.description: Get a detailed report on a specific epic to understand its complete history, current phase, key technical decisions made, and remaining work estimation for roadmap planning.
use_cases.target_user: Product managers and project managers tracking feature delivery

best_practices: Use ghe-report for detailed analysis rather than ghe-status when you need metrics, trends, or comprehensive assessments
Run health reports regularly (weekly) to catch compliance issues before they become critical
Generate epic reports before roadmap planning meetings to have complete context on feature progress
anti_patterns: Using ghe-report for quick status checks wastes time - use ghe-status instead for immediate current state overview
Ignoring health report warnings can lead to workflow violations accumulating over time
Generating reports without reviewing the output misses the opportunity for continuous improvement insights

faq.question: What is the difference between ghe-report and ghe-status?
faq.answer: ghe-status provides a quick overview of current state and active threads. ghe-report generates detailed analysis including metrics, trends, health assessments, and epic-specific deep dives.

faq.question: Can ghe-report modify my GitHub issues?
faq.answer: No. ghe-report is read-only and generates analysis reports. It does not modify issue labels, comments, or workflow state.

faq.question: How often should I run health reports?
faq.answer: Weekly health reports help catch compliance issues early. Increase frequency to daily during critical release periods.

faq.question: What data sources does ghe-report use?
faq.answer: ghe-report analyzes GitHub issue threads, phase transitions, checkpoint history, and the SERENA memory bank to generate comprehensive reports.

faq.question: Can I export ghe-report output to other formats?
faq.answer: Reports are generated as markdown text. You can copy the output to any markdown-compatible tool, documentation system, or convert it to your preferred format.

faq.question: Does ghe-report work with private repositories?
faq.answer: Yes. ghe-report works with both public and private repositories as long as the GitHub Elements plugin has appropriate access permissions.
